stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on a large, industrial Bowser-themed level. The primary focus was an extensive, iterative process of designing and implementing a background that would create the illusion of a vast ocean on N64 hardware, involving multiple failed attempts and a final, novel solution developed with feedback from Biobak. He also fixed bugs, discussed a major performance optimization discovery, and explored a potential merchandise deal.

development_findings.summary: Kaze discovered a major export error that was doubling the polygon and vertex count of his models. The game still performed well on N64 hardware even with this mistake, highlighting the efficiency of the engine.
development_findings.quote: I found out when we were in 64 testing this level and it already hit 30 FPS. I was exporting it as an F3D model and not F3DEX2. So we had twice the vertex loads, twice the triangle counts, and some other unoptimizations and it still ran fine.

development_findings.summary: Kaze determined that a standard non-scrolling background (NBG) was unsuitable for the level because the 3D geometry touches the horizon, which would create a visual disconnect.
development_findings.quote: I think the NBG is just not possible here... I can mathematically prove that this will never work. I think the idea is fundamentally wrong.

development_findings.summary: Kaze chose to use a classic Bowser switch over a generic lever to maintain design consistency with the original Super Mario 64.
development_findings.quote: I like the switch, you know why I do? It's because every Bowser level in Mario 64 uses this exact switch to help Mario beat the stage. This is just a very Mario 64 Bowser design.

development_findings.summary: Kaze fixed a significant bug that was causing crashes, leading to much greater stability for the game on original N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: I think I found the bug that caused only Up64 to crash. And now RTYI is so stable on the N64.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has adopted a newly updated version of the old NEMU64 emulator for its powerful, modern debugging capabilities, including a GDB debugger.
development_findings.quote: A new emulator dropped recently called NEMU64. Yes, NEMU, the emulator from 2002. And they updated it. And it's so much better now. And you can debug everything with it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identified several key areas for performance optimization on the N64, including implementing backface culling, sorting triangles, and creating a simplified collision map.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong programming philosophy, viewing C++ as an inferior version of C, with the exception of templates. He considers classes to be an unnecessary obstruction.
context_findings.quote: I think C++ is just a shitty version of C. Here's my hot take for the day. Actually, never mind. There's one good thing in C++ and that is templates. Templates are tolerable. I accept them. I think they're good. Classes equals bad. They are just like an unnecessary obstruction if you ask me.

context_findings.summary: A merchandise company approached Kaze about producing custom N64 boxes, sparking ideas about legally selling physical products and potentially forming a company around ROM hacking projects.
context_findings.quote: Dude, when I sell RGYI, I could just sell the box without the ROM, and it'd be legal. And then I would also make a ROM that's just the OST and sell that. Dude, we're gonna be fucking millionaires. Dude, we're gonna make a full ROM making company.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intends to pay his collaborators, including musicians, for their work if the project or related merchandise generates income.
context_findings.quote: If the set makes decent money, I have to pay you. I completely agree. I was offering to pay the musicians as well, for like the rights to the music, once everything's done.

context_findings.summary: Kaze was approached for his opinion on a conflict within the B3313 beta romhack community, but he remained neutral and uninvolved.
context_findings.quote: Apparently there's new beta Mario 64 Romhacks drama... Apparently the team that worked on one of those beta recreations has beef with the creator... and they wanted my input and my input was like yeah, he seems like a solid guy. I think that was the opposite of what they wanted.

context_findings.summary: Kaze humorously describes himself as a 'vampire' who is not well-adapted to the outdoors, preferring to stay inside.
context_findings.quote: I am not adapted well to the outside environment. I'm kinda like a vampire. I would die in the sun. I am the whitest man alive.

biobak.summary: Kaze jokingly impersonated Biobak, indicating a familiar and collaborative dynamic where Biobak's opinion on art direction is highly valued.
biobak.quote: Hi I'm Biobak and i think you should try the previous color.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a significantly improved 3D model and texture for the Bowser stage switch, which Kaze immediately praised and implemented.
biobak.quote: This is so much better than the one we had before. This actually just looks like an upgraded version of the Mario 64 one. Very, very nice.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a mock-up image for the level's background, suggesting a gradient that blends the ocean with the skybox. This idea became the foundation for the final design Kaze implemented.

badub.summary: Badub was not directly involved in this stream, but Kaze mentioned his intention to pay the musicians for the rights to their music if the project generates revenue through merchandise.

zeina.summary: Zeina's absence was noted, as she was expected to be working on an animation for a character in the level, indicating her role in bringing characters to life.
zeina.quote: Unfortunately Zeina's gone today. Otherwise, she maybe would have finished the animation for the guy here which would have been very cool.

key_stories.title: Inventing an Infinite Ocean
key_stories.summary: Kaze embarked on a lengthy and difficult process to design the level's background. After concluding that traditional methods were impossible for this specific level, he collaborated with Biobak and invented a novel hybrid 3D/2D parallax technique to create the illusion of an infinite ocean on the N64.
key_stories.challenge: The level's background looked empty and finite. Kaze needed to create the illusion of a vast, endless ocean on the N64, a console with strict rendering limitations, without the background looking 'painted on' or disconnected from the level.
key_stories.process: Kaze iterated through multiple solutions: adjusting fog, considering distant 3D models, and attempting a non-scrolling background (NBG), which he concluded was technically unsuitable. He then tried manipulating the 3D ocean model itself. Following a visual mockup from Biobak, he experimented extensively with color gradients and eventually invented a new technique combining a 3D model with a parallax background plane, requiring meticulous tweaking of its movement speed relative to the camera.
key_stories.outcome: After numerous failed attempts, Kaze developed a hybrid solution. He combined a 3D model of the ocean (with its edges curved up to create an optical illusion) with a separate background plane that moves with the camera at a slightly different rate (a parallax effect), finally achieving the desired look of a vast, integrated ocean.
key_stories.key_quote: It will never work. I can mathematically prove that this will never work. I think the idea is fundamentally wrong.

key_stories.title: The Accidental Optimization
key_stories.summary: Kaze accidentally discovered he had been using an unoptimized model format that doubled the geometric detail of his levels. The fact that the game was already running well on N64 hardware despite this major error served as a testament to the engine's performance and revealed a huge, untapped potential for optimization.
key_stories.challenge: Ensuring a large, complex level runs smoothly on original N64 hardware is a constant struggle.
key_stories.process: While testing the level's performance on an N64, Kaze investigated his asset pipeline. He discovered he was using an unoptimized model format (F3D) instead of the correct one (F3DEX2). Despite this error doubling the geometric complexity, the level was already running close to 30 FPS.
key_stories.outcome: The accidental discovery revealed that the game engine was already highly efficient. Correcting the export settings provided a massive, immediate performance boost and gave Kaze confidence that with further standard optimizations (like backface culling and triangle sorting), the level would easily meet its performance targets.
key_stories.key_quote: I was exporting it as an F3D model and not every F3DEX2. So we had twice the vertex loads, twice the triangle counts, and some other unoptimizations, and it still ran fine.

open_questions.context: A merchandise company contacted Kaze about creating and selling custom N64-style boxes for the game. Kaze was very excited by the idea and the possibility of forming a legitimate company and paying his contributors.
questions: How serious are the plans to create physical merchandise? Can you tell us more about the company that reached out?
You mentioned forming a 'full ROM making company.' Is that a serious ambition, or was it excitement in the moment? What would that look like?
You also mentioned paying the musicians and other contributors. Have you established a formal plan for revenue sharing from merch or other sources?

open_questions.context: Kaze and Biobak collaborated on the background design. Kaze implemented ideas from a mockup Biobak provided, iterating on it live. This interaction was a mix of direct implementation and creative interpretation.
questions: Can you walk me through your typical collaboration process with Biobak? How do you exchange ideasâ€”is it mostly through Discord, mockups, or live calls?
How does feedback from the art team influence your technical or design decisions? Can you give an example of when a piece of art from Biobak made you rethink a feature?
Biobak, what's it like creating art for Kaze's engine? What limitations do you have to keep in mind, and how does that affect your creative process?

open_questions.context: Kaze discovered he was using an unoptimized model format (F3D vs. F3DEX2) that doubled the polygon count, yet the game still ran well on N64 hardware.
questions: What was the moment you realized you were using the wrong model format? How long had that been happening?
What does this discovery say about the performance of the sm64ex-coop engine you've built upon?
Beyond fixing the export, what are the most critical optimization techniques you rely on to make these huge levels work on the N64?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that his wife, Zeina, was absent but would have otherwise been working on an animation for a character in the level.
questions: How do you and Zeina manage your working relationship alongside your personal one?
What are the biggest advantages and challenges of having your spouse as a key collaborator on a project like this?
Zeina, what is your process for creating animations that fit the Mario 64 aesthetic while still feeling fresh?

open_questions.context: Kaze was approached for his opinion on drama surrounding the B3313 beta romhack project. He stated he gave a neutral response that was likely not what the person wanted.
questions: What are your general thoughts on community politics and drama within the ROM hacking scene?
How do you navigate being a public figure in this space when conflicts arise between other creators?
Has your experience with past community interactions shaped how you manage the RTYI project and team?
